Requirement: Be aware of the care needed when handling a colony of honey bees;
BulletPoints: Keep in mind safety of self and, particularly, others (consider proximity to public and precautions to be taken)
Be slow and gentle when manipulating the colony in order to as much as possible keep the bees calm

Requirement: Be aware of the reactions of honey bees to smoke;
BulletPoints: Bees fear for the colony, ingest nectar/honey, and in doing so make themselves full, heavy and less inclined to sting
Make sure smoke not too hot or too much smoke is applied as the Bees may react badly

Requirement: Be aware of the personal equipment needed to open a colony of honey bees and the importance of its cleanliness;
BulletPoints: Essential – suit, gloves, smoker, hive tool, spare fuel and lighter
Desirable – bee brush, icing sugar dispenser, container for removed brace comb, container with washing soda for cleaning equipment and cover cloth
Occasional use – queen cage, queen marking pen and cage
Must clean equipment between hives and after apiary visit
Beekeepers are a conduit for the spread of disease

Requirement: Be aware of the reasons for opening a colony;
BulletPoints: To check if “queenright”
To check for sufficient stores
To check for the presence of disease
To check the results of previous manipulations
To perform new manipulations to achieve specific objectives

Requirement: Be aware of the need for stores.
BulletPoints: During the season a thriving colony requires 10lb honey to survive a week (equivalent of 2 x brood frames of stores)
Stores primarily means carbohydrate (nectar or honey) also pollen for protein to feed the brood
To provide the bees with food during the june gap, late autumn, winter and early spring months and during prolonged periods of poor weather in the “honey flow” season

Requirement: Be aware of the importance of record keeping.
BulletPoints: To help manage stocks more effectively by reminding you what you found and what you did
To help manage stocks more effectively by enabling you to plan what needs to be done next
Record information like date, weather, queen sighting, queen cells, brood, stores, space, temper, varroa, supers feed

Requirement: Be able to open a colony of honey bees and keep the colony under control;
BulletPoints: Spend a moment observing bees at the entrance before smoking in order to recognise normal behaviour
Work from behind entrance if “warm” way and side if “cold” way
Put roof upturned on floor and supers on roof, with crown board on top to prevent robbing
Check underside of excluder (or crown board) for queen and return her to the brood
Demonstrate that you are aware of the use of cover cloths, which prevent more bees from flying up and help maintain the hive temperature
Demonstrate that you are aware that sometimes using spray of tepid water can be better than smoke, as the former calms them, while the latter might panic them
Return frames in the same order

Requirement: Be able to demonstrate lighting and the use of the smoker;
BulletPoints: Show you know what fuels are available, which are coolest and that fresh grass in the top prevents hot ash being blown into the hive
Few puffs at the entrance and wait for it to take effect
Keep it alight, keep it close at hand
Occasional use and waiting for it to take effect if the bees become too agitated
Demonstrate use to control bees and drive them down before replacing parts
Know how to put it out safely, block top with grass is a good method

Requirement: Be able to demonstrate the use of the hive tool;
BulletPoints: Keep tool in hand at all times
It can be used for a variety of purposes: scraper, lever for boxes and frames
Good practice is to wash it in washing soda between hives

Requirement: Be able to remove combs from the hive and identify worker, drone and queen cells or cups if present, and to comment on the state of the combs;
BulletPoints: Remove an outermost edge frame or dummy board making space to operate

Demonstrate responsible temporary storage of removed frames: perhaps in a spare brood box or carefully propped against the hive or even leaning against the queen excluder which might be leaning up to the hive entrance
Do not “roll” bees, but use space made to move frames along then slowly lift them out
Once found, some beekeepers temporarily trap the queen in a matchbox or queen cage to avoid losing or damaging her
Recognise and comment on brood pattern (colour, age, type etc.), brace comb and spacing

Requirement: Be able to identify the female castes and the drone;
BulletPoints: Females – workers and queen (or telltale signs of Queen)

Requirement: Be able to identify brood at all stages;
BulletPoints: Eggs, larvae, pupae (sealed in cells)

Requirement: Be able to demonstrate the difference between drone, worker and honey cappings;
BulletPoints: Honey cappings are paler and waxier
Brood cappings are various biscuit shades and look more fibrous in texture
Drone cells have a larger surface area and are deeper (longer) too

Requirement: Be able to identify stored nectar, honey and pollen;
BulletPoints: Nectar is clear and uncapped,
Honey is capped
Pollen is uncapped and a range of colours
All three normally present in an arc round brood cells on the outermost frames

Requirement: Be able to take a sample of worker bees in a suitable container;
BulletPoints: Either shake bees onto an appropriate surface, e.g. Hive roof or position populated brood frame appropriately
Place the open part of a matchbox over the bees and close it before removing it from the surface

Requirement: Be able to state the number of worker bees required for an adult disease diagnosis sample;
BulletPoints: 30 or so live bees
200-300 dead bees for suspected poisoning, most likely found outside the hive

Requirement: Be able to demonstrate how to shake bees from a comb and how to look for signs of brood disease;
BulletPoints: Make space by removing two frames
Shake bees sharply from frame whilst it is still low in the brood chamber
Hold lugs firmly
Jerk firmly downwards, avoid hitting sides as you do so
May need to do a second/third time to remove all the bees

Requirement: Be able to name and explain the function of the principal parts of a modern beehive;
BulletPoints: Stand, Open Mesh Floor, Entrance Block, Brood Box, Brood Frame, Foundation, Queen Excluder, Super, Super Frame, Crown Board, Porter Escape and Roof
Different types of hive (no longer a requirement to know these):
National (commercial with deeper brood frames)
WBC, classic bee house
Langstroth, outside UK most popular hive, has jumbo
Dadant, similar to Langstroth, biggest hive available
Smith, similar to National except frames have short lugs, popular with bee farmers who move hives around

Requirement: Be able to discuss the concept of the bee space and its significance in the modern beehive;
BulletPoints: The height of a bee 3/8thinch or 6-9 mm
It is the crawl space needed by the bee to pass easily between two structures
Not so small they will propolise it <6mm
Not to large they will brace comb it > 9mm
Vertically you must opt for top or bottom bee space and not mix the two
Hoffman frames are designed to set correct space, other frame types may need spacers

Requirement: Be able to assemble a brood frame and fit it with wired wax foundation;
BulletPoints: Nails across Hoffman shoulders
Trap foundation wire loop between wedge and top bar and nail within loops
Nail up into both bottom bars

Requirement: Be able to discuss spacing of the combs in the brood chamber and super for both foundation and drawn comb and methods used to achieve this spacing.
BulletPoints: Wax foundation encourages bees to build the desired (worker or drone) sized cells in an orderly manner across the whole available surface
Brood chamber – bee space (11 or 12 frames in National)
Spacing can be achieved using Hoffman Frames, castellated spacers, metal or plastic ends
Super frames can be set wider once drawn comb is employed so more honey is stored per frame using either different castellations or size of end spacers

Requirement: Be able to give an elementary account of the development of queens. workers and drones in the honey bee colony;
BulletPoints: Queen: Egg – laid in or moved by workers to queen cell (like monkey nut hanging down)
Queen: Lava – continuously fed on royal jelly
Queen: 1-5 days after emergence – groomed and fed by workers
Queen: About 3 days wings fully open and is capable of flight
Queen: 5-14 days series of mating flights
Queen: 5 days after final mating starts to lay eggs
Queen: Continues laying productively for 2-3 years
Worker: Eggs – laid in open cells, at first erect, gradually lying down
Worker: Larvae – cared for by adult workers, Continuously fed (first 2 days royal jelly, then brood food - a mixture royal jelly, honey and pollen)
Worker: Pupae – in sealed cells, no feeding, develops into adult and emerges on its own
Worker: 1-2 days after emergence – cleans cells and warm brood nest
Worker: 3-5 days – feed older lava with honey and pollen
Worker: 6-10 days – feed younger lavae with royal jelly
Worker: 11-18 days – ripen nectar, produce wax and construct comb
Worker: 19-21 days – guarding and ventilation, take exercise and orientation flights to learn to fly and locate the hive
Worker: 22+ days – forage for nectar, pollen, water or propolis
Drone: Same development as workers, until adult stage, when only role is to mate with the Queen

Requirement: Be able to state the periods spent by the female castes and the drone in the four stages of their life (egg, larva, pupa and adult);
BulletPoints: Egg hatches: Queen - day 3; Worker - day 3; Drone - day 3
Lava sealed: : Queen - day 8; Worker - day 9; Drone - day 10
Adult emerges: Queen - day 16; Worker - day 21; Drone - day 24
Death: Queen - Upto 5 years but 2-3 years in reality due beekeeper; Worker - About 6 weeks, but 3- 6 months in winter; Drone - Until Autumn if not mated, otherwise after mating

Requirement: Be able to name the main local flora from which honey bees gather pollen and nectar;
BulletPoints: Very Early – crocus, snowdrops, flowering currant, hazel
Spring – fruit blossoms, rape, dandelions, sycamore, garden flowers
Summer- field beans, borage, garden flowers, clovers, chestnuts (propolis)
Autumn – blackberries, ivy, willowherb

Requirement: Be able to give a simple definition of nectar and a simple description of how it is collected, brought back to the hive and is converted into honey;
BulletPoints: Nectar is a sugar substance created by flowers to entice insects to visit
Nectar is up to 80% water, bees have a preference lower water content nectar
Nectar is ingested by the bee into its honey stomack and regurgitated back at the hive
Hive bees add enzymes to the nectar to break down its complex sugars and then store it in the comb
Nectar is fanned to evaporate and reduce water content to about 18% at which point it will not ferment
Finally, when ripe it is sealed under capping of wax
Nectar - Collection: Carried from flowers in honey stomach of foraging bees then processed into honey by hive bees
Nectar - Use: Food – carbohydrate for energy

Requirement: Be able to give a simple description of the collection and use of pollen, water and propolis in the honey bee colony;
BulletPoints: Pollen -  Collection: Carried from flowers in pollen baskets on hind legs (will attach to hairs all over bee until combed and pressed into baskets). Converted into bee bread / brood food by hive bees for feeding to larvae
Pollen -  Use: Food – protein for growth
Propolis - Collection: Carried from plant wounds and buds in pollen baskets
Propolis - Use: Seal cracks in hive; Reinforce and clean old comb; Entomb dead animals in hive; Limits bacterial and fungal growth;
Water - Collection: Carried in [honey] stomach; some bees are speiclaist water collectors
Water - Use: Mixed with honey before bees eat it or feed to brood; Used to cool hive on hot days – action of evaporation

Requirement: Be able to give an elementary description of the way in which the honey bee colony passes the winter.
BulletPoints: Winter workers – large fat bodies, live for up to 6 months, cluster in a hive to retain warmth, vibrate wing muscles to generate heat
Rotate positions to take turns on the colder outer edge of the cluster
10-20k workers over winter to regenerate colony in spring
No drones
Queen in centre of cluster
Warmer days water and cleansing flights, water employed on stores

Requirement: Be able to give an elementary description of how to set up an apiary;
BulletPoints: Consideration for the public
Availability of forage and water
Environment – wind, sun, damp, frost pocket, flooding, livestock
Access and space for the beekeeper
Hive Stand - ergonomic height, secure
Position close to high barrier to make bees go up
Warning notices
Strapping in high winds
Entrace direection / orientation
